creator: Isaac
name: Hacker Camp Political Parties AKA Mini M.U.D.
description:
This is an activity I already ran this year, but it’s worth recording what we did.
We split into groups of 4-5, although we should’ve kept the max at 4 per group. Each group creates 5 things.
1. The team name. This can be something from geek culture, hacker camp culture, or whatever. This year we had “The Lathe Rebellion”, “NGGYU”, and “Demopracy”
2. The slogan. This is a one sentence explanation of what the team is going to do if they win the election.
3. Hacker camp political opinions. Which doctor in Dr. Who is the best? Do we really need another lathe? The teams need to decide on their opinion on some of them. We gave about 10 examples to start from, and they had lots more.
4. The poster. This needs to be planned and has the name of the team, their slogan, and some artwork from what they are trying to do, like popcorn for the team who want to have us eat popcorn at movie nights.
5. The video. The campers decide on a filming plan for their video which might include an interview or showcase of what the team is planning on doing if everyone votes for them. They can also be edited if there’s enough time.

Lastly, at synthesis the videos are shown and all of camp votes on whichever team they like the most.


Here are some of the “political” opinions I thought of to get them started:
Should we eat strawberry pizza at camp?
Do we need another lathe?
Should we eat lunch inside or outside?
Is a movie night better or is game night better?
Which is the best room in camp?
Are hexagons really the bestagons?
Campers can also suggest more
materials: Poster paper, large pieces. Markers, pencils, normal sized paper for brainstorming. Camera/ phone camera and editing app for the video portion. Campers can’t use their phones so staff phones work well for video and editing.
goals:
The goal is to show the campers how much a team can help them complete their own goal: winning the election. They had to think of what would get the most votes and how to make it funny at the same time.

I just thought I’d mention that this activity isn’t supposed to have anything to do with real life politics.

creator: Isaac
name: Bestagons Game
description:
Invent the game that Adam and the Think Higher team wanted to make, but thought was too complicated (to prove them wrong, and also bestagons). The essence of the idea is to create a 3D board game that’s dynamic, meaning the board can look different each game. This would involve using the bestagon device to cut wooden hexagons to use in the game. Each tile serves a different purpose in the game and they can be shuffled around and stacked in different ways to make the game unique each time it’s played. It’s a long project because it involves cutting wood, painting, and brainstorming how the game is going to work. It can’t be too complicated, but it needs to have some element of skill, not just luck, although some luck is good too.


The game they made in Think Higher is super cool!
materials: Wood for bestagons, paper for brainstorming (auto correct says brainwashing??), pencils, paint & brushes, cardboard and/or cardstock for cards if we need them
goals:
Some questions to think about:
What makes a game well designed? How can we make the game fun, easy to learn, engaging, and simple, yet not too complex, all at the same time? It’s a challenge of thinking of loads of ideas but realizing that not all of them will actually work for the game. How can playtesting and balancing help make the game more fun? How can we make sure players don’t get board if it’s not their turn? How can we include players with disabilities such as color blindness or dyslexia (separate by icons vs. colors or text)?

creator: Isaac
name: Wave Function Collapse
description:
This is a coding activity.
The first half of the day involves an algorithm called "Wave Function Collapse". It's used in game design and a demo can be found here: https://jaxry.github.io/wave-function-collapse/.
We will experiment with the default options and then make our own pixel art to give the algorithm. Then, I'll explain some of the way it's coded and why certain functions make it work. The campers can even try and code a bit of the algorithm themselves, although it is very complicated.
The second half of the day is about the other meaning of "Wave Function Collapse" which comes from quantum mechanics. It explains how quantum particles can be in many different states all at the same time, but "collapse" as soon as we inspect them. With this, I'll explain how to make requests to run code on real quantum computers using Python and Qiskit (https://qiskit.org/).


Note that this activity requires explaining and sitting around for a while, which is to be expected on computer activities
materials: 0.42 computers per camper
goals: To learn about quantum mechanics, a cool algorithm, and to get the campers introduced to something that's out of their comfort zone, even if they are expert coders.
categories: Geeky, Nerdy, Computers, Gaming, Art, Explosive, Advanced

3. Explain a bit of complicated physics to the campers on how paper airplanes fly and how exactly certain parts of it affect lift and drag
4. Campers split into groups and work on designing or tweaking an existing design
5. Scientifically test the designs on the launcher and record distance to see which changes worked the best
6 (given enough time). Build the best paper airplane possible given everything learned from the day
materials: Lots of paper! Either legos or wood + motor + battery
goals: The goal is to build a super paper airplane and to learn a bit of how real planes fly. We will have to go through the design process to understand how to best construct our paper airplanes

creator: Shaiel
name: Cyanotype/Blueprints/Sun-painting with chemistry
description:
Day 1: (counselors)
Mix potassium ferricyanide (40g) into water (400ml)
Mix ferric ammonium citrate (100g) into water (400ml)
let dissolve for 24 hours

Day 2: Counselors or cool kids:
Mix equal parts of each solution.  It will be good for about 2 hours.
Paint white paper or white cloth (or both) with solution.  Let air dry in dark.
Keep paper/cloth in dark.

Day 3: Anyone
Put something dramatic (leaves, flowers, feather, et cetera) on the paper or cloth.
Cover with a sheet of glass.
Expose to sunlight for 10-20 min, keeping positions as well as possible.

It will turn yellow/amber.
Rinse in a tray of water for 5-8 min.  Rinse again, until water is clear.
Rinse in diluted hydrogen peroxide to lock the cyan in place.

Hang dry on a clothesline.  After it dries, it's not going to change colours on its own, but, oils in our hands, et cetera, might cause changes in colours.





Some parts take very little time, and some parts take more.

There's a  lot of down-time here.
materials:
White cloth and/or strong paper
potassium ferricyanide 
ferric ammonium citrate
hydrogen peroxide

(Distilled water?  Jerusalem water is very mineral-hard, so yes distilled is better.)
goals: All.  Depending how it's done.

Depending on the number of boards, and the amount of clay that is feasible to get, those factor limit the number of campers we`ll be able to have.
I'll have to test Cuneiform

Cuneiform videos
History
How-to
Royal Game of Ur:
https://youtu.be/WZskjLq040I - To get the feel of the game

Videos for your fun, might use first two for the activity
materials:
A projector to show the symbols, maybe show an instructional video 

For Cuneiform:
(Some clay), Plastecine, Cut popsicle sticks,Plastic bowls with water, We could be working on newspapers to minimize mess

For the Royal Game of Ur
A lot of dice (that need to be modified to be half covered/half normal; 4 per board [D4 if we want to be true to the original, 2 tips marked])
Paper with the board printed/drawn on it (or we could make an actual board with wood)
Back-gammon pieces (or any distinct, easy-to-play-with pieces; 14 (7 of each color) per board)
goals:
Engagement - Each camper will be pressing their own name into the clay and have a small chunk to take home with them.
Create - it's a whole cool writing system, over 5000 years old, we are re-learning, you are creating a piece of history.

We can explain a bit of how newton's physics work and how to predict where a projectile will land. We will repeat the launch at different angles/heights and record how far the projectile goes. Using some math we can find the mass and prove how to calculate the projectile's distance from an angle.


Note that we have no notes

Either lego or pink room's materials like wood
Meter stick
Computer to calculate math (maybe)
Paper to write results
goals: The students to understand some basic physics and to each feel like they contributed something to the experiment. If the experiment goes wrong (like an explosion...) the campers need to adapt and change the goals, they can learn resilience. One issue could be with air resistence.

Create a Catan gameset in the Pink Room, paint it, et cetera. . .

creator: Isaac
name: Micro mouse
description:
This project is very complicated. Step 1. either one or two teams each build a “mouse” - a small robot that has wheels to move it as fast as possible, and sensors so it knows where it is. Step 2. After discussing what a search algorithm is, we can try to implement one on the Arduino. This shows the mouse how it can move through a maze. The problem is, we need a maze. Step 3. Construct a maze from wood which is just large enough for the mice to turn and move.


This project will probably have to happen later in the summer if at all. I listed 2 days as the duration, but this is counting one day of building and one day of programming/explaining how that stuff works, and I’m not sure how or when we would build the maze.
materials: Well… there’s a lot. Shaiel already sent a picture of a bunch of Arduino parts which are very useful, although we may need infrared sensors which are used to keep the robot in a straight line, and tiny wheels and motors for it to use.
goals: Student should understand what a search algorithm is, and the basics of building small robots. The project supports teamwork and shows the value of the engineering cycle.

creator: Isaac
name: Rotoscoping
description: There are 5 steps to the plan. Step 1. Find a video or clip that is less than 30 seconds long and involves some action and isn’t too complex. One example is a video of someone throwing a ball. Step 2. Download the video, convert it to a gif file and import it into your animation software of choice (for example Krita, which is free). Put it on its own layer and reduce the opacity. Step 3. Pick a subject and/or background (it should be moving throughout the video) and carefully trace each frame one by one (this takes a very long time). Step 4. Export and present your animation to the group. Step 5. Given enough time, switch animation files with another person, and add cool effects in a new color such as explosions or dragons. Step 42. Present the animations at movie night.
materials: Computers for each camper, or each pair.
goals: The goal is to create a rotoscoped video animation.

creator: Dasi

goals: Learn about light refraction

creator: Isaac
name: Hacker Stats
description: I plan to teach basic statistics concepts, and then decide on a yes/no question or two to ask a sample of staff and campers. An example of a bad question would be, “Should we get a lathe?” because everyone would obviously say yes and it wouldn’t help anyone. Next, we would discuss types of data collection such as Stratified, Clustered, and Simple (aka the least simple) Random Sampling. The data collection would take up a significant part of the day and can also be done during lunch. Then, I would introduce the math parts which is calculating the margin of error, confidence level, and maybe the confidence interval. That tells us the approximate percentage of the whole camp who said yes/no to the question.
goals: Community, Geek

Then we plan out what combination of artifacts will best tell the story of ancient rome, and then we split into pairs in order to create them and at the end invite other campers to go through our museum and learn. (The museum tour could involve costumes and food)

creator: Eyal
name: Moral Dilemmas
description:
Begin with a game to get the campers into the mindset of evaluating something and picking a side. Set a broom down in the center of the room, give a prompt, and everyone move to where you hold on it (linear scale); starting from very pareve prompts and up to ones that people can actually have emotional investments in.
After that, we divide into groups of 3-5. Each group is given a dilemma (eg trolley problem, or publishing details of people accused of crime). They need to a) discuss the dilemma and what action they would take, and b) come up with a creative way to present the problem (and maybe their answer).
After discussion time in the small groups, each group presents their dilemma and resolution, and then the entire group can continue to debate it.
Finish by tying back to the decisions we started with -- how often we need to make a choice between two competing values, and how do we prioritize and choose?
materials:
A broom or something to mark the midpoint
Supplies for creative presentation -- could be paper+markers+scissors, could be some Lego, maybe game pieces. Either be flexible with providing supplies, or decide and limit.
goals: Intellectual discussion of moral dilemmas, in both small and big groups; creative presentation of a problem; take away something to make you think. Values of empowerment and engagement.

creator: Isaac
name: Connected Robots
description: We will use some Arduino nano microcomputers along with some WiFi chips (we still need 2 more) to build 3 small robots. One day in the summer would be spent planning and creating a concrete goal of what the robots should be able to do. Each group of 3 would Another day would be spend coding and connecting the parts together. This is the most complicated chapter of the project because I’m not completely sure how the robots would be able to move around. A final day would be spend creating and decorating a body for the robots so that they can actually move around (maybe with a bit of wood). This day would also include finishing touches on the code and fixing bugs. The days don’t have to be consecutive since each part of the project doesn’t need all of the knowledge of the previous parts, but campers would be welcome to join for multiple days.
materials: We would need to find some breadboards for doing electronics (3). We need some sort of device to move the robots such as servo motors, high speed propellor motors, and/or rolling ball controlled by evil chainsaws (Shayah’s idea). As I mentioned in the description, we need 2 more WiFi chips which are available on Amazon, but are somewhat expensive.
goals: At the end of the project, campers will have a better understanding of Arduino and how to build with them. They will also have seen how difficult it is to combine lots of small parts from each group to a whole and getting the robots to communicate.

creator: Eyal
name: Invisible Cryptography
description:
Learn about encryption methods, mostly classic but touching on modern. The basic ciphers: Caesar cipher, Atbash, Vigenere. Breaking ciphers using letter frequency analysis.
Other methods of encryption and encoding, the difference between the terms, and uses: Morse code, ASCII, pigpen (square with dots).
Prepare ahead of time encrypted texts for people to crack, at a couple difficulty levels.
Invent our own encryptions using the principles we learn.
[Discuss some of the principles of modern digital encryption. Public/private keys. Large prime numbers. Key exchange.]
Part 2: steganography -- hiding messages in plain sight. Discuss various methods of doing this, and how it depends on the type of code also. Hide our own messages, using invisible ink, or more creative methods.
materials:
Pencils and paper.
Supplies for invisible ink: lemon juice (the one i bought last year is still in the camp fridge); q-tips or paintbrush for writing; matches/candles/lighter for revealing.
goals: Understand principles of encoding, encryption, and steganography. Work together (teams of 2-3) to design their own encryption method. Hide and reveal messages with invisible ink.

creator: Dasi
name: Analysis of set
description: Figure out the best strategy to play set. How best to scan the cards, better to be the dealer etc. Also have a set tournament. Shayah and I would be judges

creator: Maayana
name: Shapeshifting 101
description: Learn about the foundations of optical illusions and why they work (psychology and physiology) through the use of face paint, make up and prosthetics. The kids work in pairs/alone (with a mirror) to turn themselves into a different creature or person (using shading to change face shape/size/bone structure). A cool way to turn into a dragon or klingon or even just turn into your friend or a completely random person. A project like this would work well with costume creation as well. Materials: mirrors, face brushes and sponges, face paint, eye shadow, foundation, palletes, wig netting, stick glue (non-toxic), bald caps? cheap wigs?, body safe latex - basically a bunch of stuff would be cool, but it's not neccesary.
materials:
Mirrors 
Face wipes
Cotton Swabs
Face sponges
Face brush/applicator
Face paint
Eyeshadow pallette (mix of colors)
Foundations (different skin tones)
Flour/Baby powder
Wig net
Small stencils
goals:
Understand the basics of viusal processing and function of the visual cortex.
Realize the power of expectation and how it influnces our perception.
Learn how colors and shading work on 3D canvases (their faces).

creator: Eyal
name: OSINT
description:
OSINT is Open Source INTelligence. The point of the project is to learn how to use the internet for information gathering from public data.

Part 1: people. Find info about people (counselors who give consent to be looked up) online. Including addresses, phone numbers, family members, photos, birthday. Use public (or semi-public) social media, phone books, Google, etc.
Part 2: photos. Have a few photos, and the goal is to identify details about where they were taken. Pinpoint location as well as possible, date/time would be a bonus.
Finally, discuss what we learned. How much data is available online. How easy it is to accidentally leak stuff from a seemingly innocent post. Potential for abuse. Ways to protect yourself.
Also worth discussing: passwords and security questions.
goals: Healthy appreciation for personal information available online. Know some techniques for finding stuff. Learn ways to make yourself safer.

creator: Eyal
name: Escape Room
description:
The yearly escape room project, but now planned and written out. The project is a full week. Strongly recommended (though we won't strictly require) that participants stay for at least 3 of the days.
Want to do a beta test Wednesday afternoon, and run the room on Thursday.

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1PWT1rW-tCJ8Dm20Mrpfpwo0VnUiKG7mbwsAwObwqcFg/edit?usp=sharing
materials:
Locks (have a bunch in the stuff room). Lockable boxes (have a few, can add latches to the wooden Lego crates). Pencils and paper. A safe?
More supplies as determined in the design phase.
Presumably albad.
goals:
Goals for the escape room team: Design, create, and run an escape room in a week. Learn about and create various types of clues/puzzles. Work together on a big project and coordinate between teams. Guide participants through the room as a mentor/assistant. Aligns strongly with Empowerment core value, as well as create/design.
Goals for participants: Play and solve the escape room clues, working together as a team.

creator: Shraga
name: calming painting
description: Paint with campers in a Bob Ross Esq style
materials: Paper, paintbrushes, paint
goals: Campers will be calm and have painted something they thought they couldn't

creator: Option 42
name: How to Beat Your Friends in Every Single Game
description:
Taking different board games (those for 2 players), and playing them. Through playing them we can learn different strategies to the game. Games such as connect 4, qorridor (or however it's spelled), etc. The campers will the play the games and then discuss in small groups how the game worked and what strategies were implemented or can be. Counselors walk around and give tips and demonstrate some strategies.
Alternatively two campers at a time demonstrate a game, and then the whole group together discusses strategies. Best to probably do a combination of both.
materials: Different board games, as many copies as possible
goals: learned new strategies to games

creator: Shraga
name: Magizoological biology
description: Apply real world physics and biology to figure out how to make mythical creatures real.
materials: Room, whiteboard, a few computers
goals: Worked with people to figure out the effects of such creatures on culture, economy, religion, etc. What changes to reality would need to be made to make them exist, and what those would affect, etc.

creator: Eyal
name: Robot Obstacle Course
description:
Run an obstacle course for Lego robots using the boards Shaiel built for the Purim activity.

Split students into groups of 2-3. Demonstrate a basic simple robot design, and present the boards. (Probably put a few together.)
Challenge: build a robot (typically based on the core design) to complete each challenge board as well as possible, with minimal changes between boards. This will involve selecting appropriate tires for each challenge to deal with the unique setup (different levels of friction, incline, maneuverability).
Run the robots by remote control (phone app).
materials:
Obstacle course challenge boards (already built). Lego robotics kits (NXT is ok).
Prepare a few basic robots ahead of time.
goals:
Build a basic robot and complete all the challenges. Appreciate the differences between tire types and why some are better suited for certain environments. Test different options to make the best design. (A few metrics: fast overall, fast on a specific board, minimal changes when changing boards.)
[Use the boards Shaiel built and was saying how they'll never be used again]

creator: Daniel
name: Dungeons & Impov
description: The intention of this activity is to allow new D&D players a taste of DMing without having to fuss over the exorbitant amount of rules. I would like to make an extremely simplified character build and monster rules, this is so the new DMs and players can improve without drowning in mechanics.
materials:
Pencils and paper
D&D dice
goals:
Train new DMs in the art of running a game.
Teamwork between players.
Train improve in a D&D like game without the rules.

creator: Daniel
name: A New Clear perspective on nuclear energy
description: Teach campers the truth about nuclear energy and how it can be used to help with global warming as well as debunking common misconceptions about nuclear energy.
goals: Raise awareness for nuclear energy and its benefits.

creator: Daniel
name: Advanced D&D
description: A 3 day game of Dungeon & Dragons, made for players who have playing D&D. anyone who is knows the rules enough to play without needing to be walked through the steps. Better if: you have been in this activity previously, you have been in the beginner activity a few times, if you have played outside of camp more than a few times.
materials:
1-3 D&D PHB's
DMG
Pencils and character sheets
If it is possible I would prefer to have access to D&D beyond(on 1 to a few computers) and a printer to streamline the character creation process.
goals: Teamwork to a mutual (although fictional) goal. Give D&D players a place to play that they can trust will be consistent.

creator: Daniel
name: Beginner D&D
description: A 3 day game of Dungeon & Dragons, made for new players as a good first time experience. focusing on explaining the rules and playing through different aspects of D&D. Good for anyone who has played from 0 to a few times but wants to go slow through the rules.
materials:
1-3 D&D PHB's
DMG
Pencils and character sheets
If it is possible I would prefer to have access to D&D beyond(on 1 to a few computers) and a printer to streamline the character creation process.
goals:
Teach and bring new players to D&D,
Teamwork to a mutual (although fictional) goal.

creator: Tsivia
name: Murder mystery
description: We learn the rules of the game murder mystery, everyone then creates there own persona (e.g. mr green, a carpenter, carries a tool box with him constantly, has anger issues) then we would create separate cards of scenarios where someone is murdered, then we would solve the mystery. It could be the typical game on a board, or it could be an all out investigation with an evidence/conspiracy pinboard… and hopefully the murder will be solved .
materials: Card to make our cards and markers, some envelopes and a cork board with pins and strings
goals: Investigation skills, team work, rules of deduction, just having fun

creator: Daniel
name:
Cup Drop Challenge
resisting gravitational acceleration by creating contraptions to carry containers of di- hidrogen monoxyde
description: Classic egg drop with a twist. instead of an egg you have a standard coffee cup with a cover full of water. The goal is to drop the cup from about 2 meters with the least amount of water spilled with the materials are given.
materials: 2 bags of marshmallows, large piece of cardboard, foam, 5 plastic bags, string, hot glue, scissors, 1 pack of skewers, 1pack of straws
goals:
A physical understanding of soft landings.
Teamwork, making one project with multiple people.
How to make do with the resources you are given.

creator: Bina
name: Axis and Allies
description: Give the kids some background about world war 2 and then teach them how to play axis and allies (its complicated so learning will probably take a little while) and then play the game.
materials: Axis and allies board and instructions. I can bring these
goals: Learning some history, developing long term strategy, focusing on multiple fronts, dealing with set backs, competitive and team work at the same time.

creator: Bina
name: Finding a solution for global warming
description: Our world is pretty much heading towards distruction thanks to what humans do. In this activity We explain the phenomenon in general in order to give background. we present the kids with all kinds of data regarding the big causes for the rising tempertures and with potential steps that could be taken in order to slow it down along with their consequences. The kids will be required to figure out the best plan in order to minimize global warming to a certain level while disrupting the 21st century life style the least possible
materials: Sheets of paper and some pens
goals: Raising awareness to the harmful effects of global warming, putting together information, finding solutions rather than ignoring, team work

creator: Bina
name: Making a model out of matches
description: We make a design plan for something we'll make out of matches (for instance: a house). Once we finish that we get to work and make it
materials: Hot glue, a ton of matches (at least 100 boxes or so, probably more)
goals: Developing the artistic side of them, working according to a plan, working on fine motoric skills, consistant and slow work until the final result

creator: Bina
name: Baking with chemistry
description: We start by learning how different factors impact baking of a product (like temperture, shape, amount of a certain ingrediant) and then bake cookies or something based on that
materials: 3 bowls, 3 forks, chocolate chip cookies ingredients ×3, an oven
goals: Fun, delicious (hopefully), learning some kitchen skills and some science

creator: Matan G
name: Writing and Performing a play
description: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1qxv6t9V25E6oTT7TwuDskDLc91g3Tc2LIPGyPK2nQs8/edit
materials: Laptops or computer room (or both, depending on interest in skit writing). Printing copies of the skits would be useful for rehearsals. Though this can be done at home by staff.
goals:
Improving and connecting ideas, Learn acting, Teamwork
See document for expansion

creator: Bina
name: Debate
description: We presnt the kids with a controversial topic, give some tips as to how to make a convincing argument. then split them into two groups and give each one a side in the dilemma. They have some time to prepare their arguments and then a debate is held in front of the camp/ some staff members.
materials: None, but would be fun if everyone wears ties during the debate
goals: Critical thinking, team work, complex understanding of an issue, public speaking

creator: Bina
name: Catan hackercamp expansion
description: Spend a day learning and playing the various catan expansions, so we make sure everyone gets the idea. Then we create our own expansion and play with it
materials: 2 basic catan games and the deifferent expansions (people can bring from home), some papers and pens, maybe wood - could go in many directions
goals: Fun, strategy development

creator: Matan HF
name: Custom Magic the Gathering set
description: Start by broadly explaining how to play magic the gathering, then decide together on themes and special abilities for the set, split into groups and make cards (we can make twelve or nine cards per piece of a4 paper, we need to write the text for the cards, and we don't have to but we can draw small pictures for them as well). Hopefully we can finish this part before lunch break. When we are back we can split into pairs and play different game types using the set. (Draft or Seald)
materials:
40 x A4 papers (80 if we have a lot of people)
Scissors
Writing materials
Dice (maybe we can make substitutes)
goals: Made a full set of about 200-300 cards with themes and flavour
categories: Nerdy, Gaming, Card game enthusiasts (ugio magic etc)

creator: Tsivia
name: Bob Ross activity
description: A step by step painting session/class in the chill style of a bob ross video. The plan is to unlock our inner chill, find the beautiful mistakes in life, maybe make some people (happy) cry with the beauty of art… who knows
materials: Acrylic paints, brushes, cups for water, tissue paper to wipe the brushes, paint pallets, canvases, and a speaker for some meditative music.
goals: Unlocking the campers true art potential, just to enjoy painting, and a way to express ourselves through art.

creator: Eyal
name: Our Future Robot Overlords and the Dark Magic Inside Them
description:
AI/ML. Details are written out, with resource links:
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Sn-q733hIRsAl6dZMMpfMkIOCFk7CWUJM8NK7GlTb6Y/edit?usp=sharing
materials:
Laptops with camera; things to classify.
For TinySorter: Raspberry Pi, TinySorter printout (on cardstock/thick paper), small LEGO pieces to sort (e.g. pins)
goals:
- Learn the basic principles behind how computers can “think” at a high level
- See / play with various examples of AI at work
- Work together to train an AI model
- Discussion of risks of AI for making decisions, including bias and accountability

creator: Eyal
name: Uncanny valley
description: Want to explore the uncanny valley -- introduce the concept, various examples, try and pinpoint what causes the tipover into the valley, and can we get something out? Is that point different for different people?
goals: (Deeper) understanding of the uncanny valley, ??

creator: Dasi
name: Lego marble run
description: Build a kind of marble run. Instead of building one where you move it you build a conveyer belt that is vertical or at least angled up, and then put pieces on so that when you let it run you try and not let the marble fall while also letting it keep running for as long as possible
materials: Legos
goals: Learn a bit about lego robotics and have a working marble run type thing

creator: Dasi
name: Lego "video game
description: Build a lego conveyer belt with pieces attached. You make it turn I don't know lego robotics so I don't know how and attach a stick you can move and then try and avoid the pieces
materials: Legos
goals: Learn a bit about robotics and build a cool game

creator: Dasi
name: Air vortex cannons
description: Build an air vortex  cannon. Find a big container like a garbage can, and stretch a sheet of rubber over one end. Side note, make sure both ends are open or cut before. You will end up with an open end and a rubber end. You pull back the rubber and let go and it shoots air
materials: Garbage can or some other plastic large container and a sheet of rubber
goals: Learn a bit about aerodynamics and build a really cool cannon

creator: Hodayah
name: Conlangs 2.0
description: Create yet another constructed language, including phonetics, morphology, grammar, syntax and more.
materials: Pencils and paper
goals: Learning the basics of language, creating a well fleshed out language, learning to speak and write in it

creator: Dasi
name: Karaoke
description: Karaoke
materials: Computer and microphone
goals: Get out energy and have fun

creator: Dasi
name: making bumper stickers for matans car
description: Buy a sheet of magnet(the kind that they make bumper stickers out of) and decorate them. ideas were brought up to make lightning mcqueen, hacker camp logo and more
materials: Magnets and markers
goals: Have everyone participate in an activity that is semi permanant and Decorate the car

creator: Hodayah
name: Cardboard arcade game 2.0
description: Make another cardboard arcade game
materials: Even more pizza boxes, hot glue. Lots of hot glue.
goals: Made another cardboard arcade game

creator: Hodayah
name: Flatulence is no laughing matter (resubmitted)
description: Record fart sounds using a bicycle pump and edit the pitches to make music
materials: Bicycle pump, a few computers with a pitching program
goals: Learning a bit about music (tempo, pitch, etc.), learning how to pitch music, laughing a bit too much, probably rickrolling camp

creator: Bina
name: Play
description: Start by teaching about some eventful time in history, and then we write a hacker camp style play script that tells a story from that time (fore example- julius ceaser). We make the costumes, give out roles and eventually show it to the rest of the camp
materials: Lots of cloth, huge papers (for background) glue, scissors. Probably some more things, what exactly and amounts depends on the plot line and number of kids participating
goals: Learn some history, creativity, performing in front of a crowd, working with a team

creator: Matan G
name: LEGO EV3 Shooting Mechanism
description: Kids build LEGO Shooting Mechanisms. What we will be shooting is something like ping pong balls. Define a distance from which to shoot (based on our own testing of what is in the realm of possibility) and have a מטרה (more points for accuracy). Throughout the day people build and calibrate their shooters to try and make it as accurate and far reaching as possible.
materials:
LEGO, 6-8 EV3 bricks, 20 LEGO EV3 Motors (could be done with normal LEGO motors without EV3)

Note: these are all estimates and depend on the amount of kids doing the activity, we have enough LEGO anyway
goals:
Teamwork, project will be in groups. This is the type of thing where you have lots of different ideas. The team needs to work out how to have everyone’s voice be heard and have it be a joint effort.

Problem solving, through the shooting of these balls, you do get to understand a lot about how changing certain parts of the mechanism affects the shooter and what stuff you need to change.

What they should practically have accomplished: a cool shooter which shoots balls accurately quite far.

creator: Shayah
name: Brewing
description: Basically, it's a full day to multi day activity where we teach the kids the science and history of brewing alcohol, and then make a brew of our own, likely cider or beer. The brew will be kept at a very low ABV so we won't be getting the kids drunk or anything like that.
materials: Basic classroom supplies, brewing keg/s, yeast (ale/lager types, base fruits (or vegetables), filter
goals: Enrichment of knowledge, fun ideas, possibly a cool result to share with camp

creator: Tsivia
name: Recreating classic scenes
description: In this activity the child or group of children can choose a favorite movie or tv show, and then choose a 10 minute scene from that movie to recreate shot by shot. Costumes will be a big part of this activity, as well as props, and backgrounds. The aim is to copy the scene down to the camera angle, edited the same way, and then possibly the scenes can be shown at lunch or the next day depending on how long the activity will take.
materials: Video cameras, phones may be fine, computer with movie editing software such as iMovie, costumes (self made) and background props (also self made)
goals: Understanding cinematography and portraying emotions through film, and just for fun.

creator: Tsivia
name: Life sustainable terrarium
description: Creating a small world where snails and other creatures can live. The activity would start with research, how to make a terrarium that will sustain life as well as it’s self, it must have enough oxygen flow and plants that give oxygen, as well as the correct soil and vitamins. If a camper wants, they can even add little fairies or clay mushrooms to make their terrarium more fantasy-like.
materials: Glass jars or containers, moss and other small plants , dirt, clay, plant friendly glue, computers and books for research
goals: Have a basic understanding of eco systems, exercising their green thumb abilities.

creator: Tsivia
name: Themed chess set making
description: Everyone can make their own (or maybe in groups) themed chess set with clay, either colored clay, or plain clay that would be painted after. By themed chess set I mean that if it were a forest chess set, the pawns could all be mushrooms, the queens could be trees etc and the board it self could be in the themed colors. Or, if someone is feeling particularly ambitious they could make, for example, a Star Wars set, which possibly the black side could be “the dark side” and the white side would be the good guys.
materials: Clay, either air drying or bake-dry, and paint. Maybe some rulers too
goals: Being able to plan a chess set that works, needing to measure the board and pieces to make sure they will stand and fit, and to be creative and technical with their hands and the small details.

creator: Hodayah
name: Pop goes the culture
description: We will look at some common tropes in pop culture which may be harmful, discuss them and how media shapes and is shaped by culture. Ask - what can we do about it? How can we be more aware and make others aware? Maybe rewrite some scenes we saw .  Discuss what this means for us at camp as a community. Is there anything we would like to change?
materials: Some good critical thinking
goals: Reaching a deeper understanding of the influence of pop culture. Developing skills to be aware of messages conveyed through media. Creating practical solutions and steps forward, in camp and in general

creator: Hodayah
name: The Great Animation Project That is Not Stop Motion For a Change.
description: Create a short video, Hacker Camp style, using the program Adobe Character Animator. We will start by planning the story and writing a script (hopefully one day, may slide into the second day as well). The second day will involve finishing the first day's work and customizing the puppets and backgrounds we will use. (Although these can be created from scratch, we will probably not do that because it will add too much time to the process.) Third -Fifth days will be spent recording voiceovers and animating, in hopes to get it done in one week. (With a bit of post production and editing during the next week).
materials: We will need several computers (not from the computer lab) and possibly a few adobe subscriptions (set up like Ariella and I did last year for our Photoshop activity).
goals: Making an animation, learning a bit about various programs, doing a lot of teamwork and planning, understanding how many different components go into making a short film, freeing Matan from servitude to the gods of stop motion, setting a time goal and sticking to it as much as possible, for a change.

creator: Hodayah
name: Lego mosaic(s)
description: Plan and make a mosaic using 2x2 lego bricks, possibly looking at mosaics, pointillism and pixel art for inspiration.
materials: Lego, Lego and more Lego
goals: Creating a mosaic (or a few, depending on the number of campers who show up), learning a little bit about the artistic background to mosaics and/or color theory
categories: Art, Advanced insofar as the participants have to be patient and understand they're not their to build random things.

creator: Hodayah
name: Woodburning
description: Try out some woodburning, maybe decorate or mark some wooden things we have in the pink room (discussed beforehand, obviously) or else just work on some blank wood or scraps.
materials: Wood of some kind (need to discuss if there's anything preconstructed we want to work on), soldering irons/woodburning kits. I have one but we probably need at least two or three to be able to run the activity.
goals: Planning a project and completing it. Discovering what difficulties there are when woodburning and how to overcome them. Strengthening ideas of safety. Burning wood and hopefully not fingers. Sniffing wood fumes.

creator: Hodayah
name: Stamp making
description: Learn various ways of making stamps and... make stamps.
materials: Need to look more into materials when it's run. Possibilities include crafting foam, erasers, cardboard, potatoes, some form of rubber, cardboard. Either way crafting knives and glue will be necessary.
goals: Made a few stamps, discovered what techniques create which effects/which advantages and disadvantages each has, experimented with different ways of stamping (ink, paint etc.), understood the principle of creating a mirror image.

creator: Hodayah
name: Building fantasy buildings
description: Learn a little bit about architecture (probably more in a design way than in a engineering way, unless anyone happens to know more about engineering than I do and wants to help me run it) and then make plans for fantasy buildings as described in books/made up. I'm mostly thinking of Hogwarts but it could also be anything else.
materials: Need to check whether we have rulers but otherwise just paper, pencils and erasers. (And books)
goals: Understood a bit about planning of buildings, used literary skills to find information in books, created a building plan, considered necessary compromises when working in a team/trying to balance design and functionality.

creator: Dasi
name: Geocaching
description: Learn about how geocaching works and try to find a few
materials: Just an app
goals: Learning how to read a map and geocache

creator: Dani
name: Bookmark making
description: I’m thinking if it’s a fast day or a day where everyone has a bagrut and we just need some extra chill activities that one person can handle: We draw our favorite characters or whatever you want on paper or white cardboard or something then we put packing tape on both sides or laminate it… then we punch a hole through the top and we do friendship bracelet style braids with the colors of your choosing which we tie onto the end… and then bam bookmark+ Of course talking about books we like and probably movie characters and what not
materials: Paper, markers, pencils and crayons (general art supplies), packing tape or a form of lamination, rolls of string (preferably in cool colors)
goals: Making a cool useful bookmark that we made, celebrating our love of books meets celebrating our love of geek culture

creator: Dani
name: GameSHOW theory
description:
Phase 1: We look at game shows through the years, what works what doesn't work, what was memorable and *game-changing* and why it worked and why was it so entertaining

Phase 2: create our own game show weather we need to build a wheel or make some sort of fancy kahoot… all based on our discoveries from phase 1 

Phase 3: make synthesis a little early and have live volunteers from other activities come compete… Have the campers who were part of the activity host (don’t worry we will practice are game show host voices)
materials: Art supplies unknown as the game show itself is unknown… but I’m thinking bow ties… as upon request maybe like 5 bow ties
goals: A game show made by brilliant minds probably full of memes, teamwork, creativity
categories: Innovative, I could be any of these

creator: Eyal
name: Excellence (spreadsheets 101)
description:
Learn how to use spreadsheet software, covering basic formula usage and filter/sort tools to pivot tables and charting.
I would love to then use the spreadsheet of campers (redacted to only first+last name, age, gender, weeks at camp, and city). We can apply the tools we learned to answer questions such as what is the average age, in what week do we have the most geographically diverse population (# cities / # campers), how does the age/gender breakdown change over the course of the summer.
Alternately, we could use a different data set, or even collect our own survey responses to analyze.
materials: Data to use
goals:
- Be familiar with spreadsheet software
- Learn useful tools for life in the area of data analysis
- Discover and discuss individual (small group) conclusions from the data we analyze

creator: Dasi
name: Decorating magnets for a car
description: Buy sheets of magnets, the kind that is used in bumper stickers and decorate the car that matan will be driving to camp. It  can have the TLW logo, or alternatively some ideas were to make it look like lightning mcqueen.
materials: We need to purchase sheets of magnet and probably already have markers in camp.
goals: creative, Fun, and decorate matans car

creator: Dasi
name: Flatuence is no laughing matter
description: Make fart noises with a bicycle pump, record and pitch them, and put it together as music
materials: Bike pump

creator: Dasi
name: Lego video game
description: Build a form of Lego video game. using a Lego robotics motor(I am not well versed in Lego robotics so don't know the exact one) and build a conveyer belt type thing that has small obstacles and using a steering wheel you have to maneuver around them for as long as possible.
materials: Legos and Lego robotics parts
goals: Learn a bit about Lego robotics and how to build a Lego video game

creator: Dasi
name: air vortex cannon
description: Build an air vortex cannon. similar to the small tubes when you pinch the rubber and when you let it go it makes a pop. but make it huge. strong enough to knock over small objects in it's path.
materials: large cylindrical plastic tub possibly a garbage can, rubber sheet large enough to cover the bottom, saw to cut the tub, and probably other stuff
goals: learn about tools and how air moves. build a really cool thing

creator: Eyal
name: Film cameras
description: Something with learning about film, even making film

creator: Hodayah
name: Conlangs
description: Discuss what components exist in a language and create a conlang (constructed language) which can communicate basic ideas. Possibly write a short dictionary and compilation of grammar rules.
materials: Paper and pencils, possibly a computer
goals: Create understanding as to the structures of languages and create a language for the use of the campers.

creator: Dasi
name: Movie commentary for the masses
description: Pick a movie say Monty python and watch it while simultaneously commenting on every part like when we watched a Knight's tale. Enjoy the comments and laugh a lot
materials: Movies and a way to play them
goals: Laugh a lot and just a fun activity

creator: Keren
name: Making it of fabric a thing that goes on your face
description:
Explain the basics behind sewing and how to sew with either a sewing machine or by hand whatever we have access to.
Then each camper can decorate their fabric for their mask before they cut it and put it all together and each camper can either sew on their design which is more complicated or just color it on with special fabric markers then they're going to have to sew their mask and they can decide if they want elastic around their ear or they can go freestyle and try to make a different supporter to go around your head I think that's about it.
materials: Enough fabric to make masks for everyone who will participate so about 20 kids preferably in the color white it has to be non stretch material 100% cotton, elastic for the part of the mask that needs it, needles, thread in all colors that are available the more the better, sewing machines if there are available, fabric markers (markers that you can write on fabric without it coming off in the laundry), fabric scissors, an iron if possible. I think that's it
goals: Each camper to end up knowing how to do basic stitches and hopefully end up with a mask

creator: Eyal
name: Communicative challenges in aerial navigation (drone flying)
description:
Flying a drone KTANE style, where one party can see the drone but not control it, and the other controls it but doesn't see it. Except now with a failure to communicate well, something could actually blow up (or crash).

Begin with teaching the mechanics of flying the drone. Move to practice flying very simple missions, one student at a time (takeoff, go to a point, navigate through something, return and land). Expect this to use one battery (~25 mins) by the time everyone gets a chance.
Then, pair students up. Each pair designs one or two missions, each of which should be doable in about a minute, no more than two. The students will then execute the missions in their pairs standing back to back, where one controls and the other instructs navigation, obstacles, etc. Switch roles between missions. Close counselor supervision is a must.
Finally, discuss. What are the pros and cons of flying solo vs with a partner? How much does the controller actually need to see?
materials: DJI Mavic Pro; cellphone with controller app installed
goals:
Experience working in pairs in a relatively high-stakes environment, where each must trust their partner; and evaluate pros and cons of solo vs pairs.
Operate a DJI Mavic drone.

creator: Eyal
name: Boomwhackers
description:
Learn how boomwhackers work at a basic level, make our own, and play some music.
Pre-activity prep: make a few, enough to play Mary Had A Little Lamb (4 notes). Gives us experience in making them and knowing how, what material, etc. Also prepare color-coded sheet music.
Activity: Begin with a demo. Explain the basic principles of how the length of the tube affects the pitch of the sound and relations between the note wavelengths. Make a set of a couple octaves by cutting tubes to the correct lengths. Then we can start to play. Some Star Wars themes can be done.
materials: PVC pipe (i think, or something like that) and something to cut it with (i don't know the pink room well enough to say)
goals: Understand the basic music theory; work together to create the music (much more than one person can do alone).

creator: Matan G
name: Writing an episode of Phineas and Ferb
description: Analyze a selection of the best episodes of Phineas and Ferb. And then brainstorm our own episode based on the template. Write a full script for it.
goals: Learn about writing and what makes a good story

creator: Ariella
name: Newton's Come to Camp
description: Do physics experiments! In the morning, we'll learn some physics: Newton's laws and other stuff based on the experiments chosen. Then we'll do the experiments and witness physics coming true
materials:
מסילה חסרת חיכוך, מכונית ניוטונית חסרת חיכוך, משקולות, משקל, סוללה, נגד משתנה, תיילים, נורת להט, סרגל התנגדות 
This is for the experiments I know. We can adapt based on what equipment we have
goals:
1. Learning basic physics 
2. Implementing the knowledge

creator: Isaac
name: Chess Modifications
description: We are going to teach the students/ campers about the design process. This will be used to create modifications to chess. For example, playing the game with four players or adding new types of pieces. They will play test, see how the changes affect the game, and lastly create new strategies that work with the changes they created.
materials: Paper and chess boards with additional pieces to possibly add or computers to design changes.
goals: To hack chess in groups and learn about the design process.
categories: Creative, Analytical, Innovative, Geeky, Gaming, Explosive

creator: Ariella
name: Blowing Up
description: Take a game and make it big, like real life big. We'll create the parts and then play the game. On the beginning we'll choose a game and learn about it.
materials: Art supplies (paint, בריסטול, cardboard..) not sure yet, we can work with anything
goals:
1. Creative thinking 
2. Having fun and playing games

creator: Hodayah
name: Making pop up books (more creative name welcome)
description: Write a story and teach basic principles of making pop ups in the morning, divide the story between the campers and have every two campers illustrate and create a pop up for their part of the story. Then join everything to one book.
materials: Paper, drawing materials, scissors, glue, tape
goals: Teaching writing stories, pop ups, creating a book, working together to create one thing

creator: Ariella
name: Analyzing the idea behind fun
description: First, we will look into the ideas behind games: how they are created, what makes them fun, different elements in games, and more. Then we will use that information to create our own game or edit an existing one.
materials: Games
goals:
1. Learning how games work
2. Implementing the knowledge of games to create a new one

creator: Adi
name: Creating awesome together
description: Making a mural out of 4 larg papers- planing what ww want yo make, teqms of two work on each paper and swich around.
materials: 4 large papers and any art supplies ww can get- psint, brushes,
goals: Geting campers to work together yo make somthibg beutiful for camp

creator: Matan G
name: LEGO Maze
description: Plan and build a complex LEGO Maze which will be made or have to be solved by someone else using various moving mechanisms
materials: LEGO
goals: Creativity, teamwork and coordination

creator: Ruvi
name: Physical full adder
description: Making a full adder out of physical components as opposed to electrical circuits.
materials: Pink room, board of wood, white board
goals: Understanding basic logic gates and circuitry and how computers do arithmetic.

creator: Eyal
name: Our Future Robot Overlords and the Dark Magic Inside Them (AI)
materials: Laptops, LEGO for sorting, Arduino
goals:
Learn the basic principles behind how computers can “think” at a high level
See / play with various examples of AI at work
Work together to train an AI model
Discussion of risks of AI for making decisions, including bias and accountability
